Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Changes in Molecular Gas and Galaxy Properties Over Time in the Era of Integral Field Unit Surveys
Award.AbstractNarration:
Part 1

Changes of a galaxy's properties over time are driven by the quantity of its cold gas, the raw material from which stars form. Thus, understanding the properties of a galaxy's cold gas component will tell us both how the star formation process changes over time and how this affects galaxies. Using a recently completed survey of carbon monoxide gas in a sample of nearby galaxies, the proposers will (1) measure how the molecular gas is used up, in order to test how star formation in the galaxies is affected; (2) map the locations of this gas in the galaxies to determine if/how these locations affect star formation; and (3) measure how the gas is flowing into and out of the galaxies to determine how this affects structural changes in the galaxies over time. In particular, some questions that can be answered from this research include: What factors affect the conversion of molecular gas into stars? How is molecular gas structured? How do galaxies grow and age? This proposal will provide insight into the process of galaxy formation and our understanding of these objects.


Part 2

This proposal plans to combine spatially resolved spectroscopy of carbon monoxide molecular gas, ionized gas and stellar populations for a sample of 125 nearby galaxies. Measuring spatially-resolved molecular gas depletion time scales as a function of various galaxy properties, using diagnostics of spectral lines to probe diffuse molecular gas, and constraining the rates of gas in- and outflow for these galaxies has the potential to add greatly to our understanding of star formation in normal galaxies.

Observations of galaxies across a range of redshifts allow us to witness the growth and aging of the galaxy population. It has long been recognized that these processes are driven by the rise and fall of star formation, which is ultimately linked to the supply of cold gas. Further progress in understanding the regulation of star formation in galaxies, however, requires additional observational constraints beyond the molecular gas mass and star formation rate. By exploiting a unique combination of the largest, most homogeneous interferometric CO survey of galaxies to date (the Extragalactic Database for Galaxy Evolution, or EDGE) and one of the principal ongoing optical integral field unit (IFU) surveys (CALIFA), the project team will confront models of star formation and galaxy evolution with uniform, high quality measurements of gas masses and star formation rates, supplemented by a vast array of additional data, including star formation history, stellar mass, nuclear activity, and the metallicity and kinematics of the gas and stars. These studies will be conducted on a spatially resolved basis across a well-defined sample that is representative of the nearby Universe, and will thus inform future studies of star formation and mass assembly at all redshifts undertaken by JWST and ALMA.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project linked CO interferometry with optical IFU data for more than 100 well-resolved galaxies, producing information on how galaxies consume (and ultimately exhaust) their gas and change over time. Specifically, we measure the spatially resolved molecular gas depletion time as a function of size scale and galaxy properties to identify environmental dependencies and test theoretical models of star formation regulation. We also used molecular line diagnostics, including line widths and isotopic CO line ratios, to map the locations of diffuse molecular gas which could systematically bias estimates of the star formation efficiency. And we also made both direct and indirect measurements of gas inflow and outflow rates to determine how feedback, interactions and accretion affect galaxy evolution.

Across the entire sample, we ﬁnd that high-mass (>5*10^10 Msun) galaxies show longer gas depletion times than low-mass galaxies, but that the sizes of the CO, stellar, and star-forming disks are all very comparable (Bolatto et al. 2017). Focusing on a smaller set of less-inclined galaxies with extended star formation, we identify a population that shows high SFR but "normal" CO content in the central region: these conditions appear intermediate between outer disks and starbursts (Utomo et al. 2017). We have used the molecular gas kinematics to test the accuracy of various approaches for deriving circular velocities from observed stellar kinematics (Leung et al. 2018). We ﬁt rotation models to the molecular and ionized gas data and ﬁnd that the rotation of ionized gas lags relative to molecular gas, as expected from a thick ionized disk (Levy et al. 2018). This work was expanded to include a characterization of lagging ionized gas haloes in highly-inclined galaxies (Levy et al. 2019). We have found that interacting galaxies in the EDGE sample show 12CO/13CO ratios about twice as large (on average) as normal galaxies (Cao et al., in prep.) However, the line ratio shows no strong trends with resolved properties such as radius, stellar surface density, and star formation activity. To investigate how star formation is inﬂuenced by factors other than the gas density, we have examined the relationship between the gas depletion time and the dynamical time in Colombo et al. (2018), adopted a data-driven approach to amulti-parameter star formation law in Dey et al. (2019), and focused on the role of hydrostatic pressure in setting the star formation ratein Barrera-Ballesteros et al. (in prep.). The latter two papers in particular have highlighted the inﬂuence that the gas velocity dispersion exerts on the depletion time. A recently accepted paper (Colombo et al. 2020) uses a combination of interferometric and single-dish molecular gas data to investigate how star forming galaxies are quenched into the red cloud, finding thata diminishing gas fraction plays a role in driving them into the green valley, while a decrease in the star formation efficiency is what determined whether they are retired. In Villanueva-Llanos et al. (inprep.) we investigate the local drivers of star formation efficiency, finding an association between molecular gas abundance and Toomre Q so that more gravitational unstable regions at a given radius have more molecular material. In Sanchez et al. (in prep.) we characterize the connection between the global and local scaling relations between SFR, gas, and stellar surface densities, and investigate the presence of secondary relations.

We have developed a database for accessing uniformly convolved and sampled image data to explore local correlations between quantities. Several versions of the database (a full version providing data cubes, and more portable versions providing 2D maps) are being readied for public release in early 2021. All maps and cubes have been publicly released already at our website (http://www.astro.umd.edu/EDGE). We have also generated an initial set of data visualizations which can be accessed from a single web page (https://mmwave.astro.illinois.edu/edgedata/). These will be usefulfor quick inspection by researchers as well as for educational purposes.
